sen.j: 道昌（どうしょう、延暦17年3月8日 (旧暦)（798年4月2日） - 貞観 (日本)17年2月9日 (旧暦)（875年3月20日））は、平安時代前期の僧。
sen.e: Dosho (April 2, 798 - March 20, 875) was a Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.
Dosho (April 2, 798 - March 20, 875) was a Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.
Dosho (April 2, 798 - March 20, 875) was a Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.
His secular surname was the Hata clan.
His secular surname was Hata.
His secular surname was Hata.
He came from Kagawagun in Sanuki Province.
He came from Kagawa Country in Sanuki Province.
sen.cmt: 「香川郡」を用語集を参照に直しました。
sen.e: He came from Kagawa Country in Sanuki Province.

sen.j: 14歳で奈良元興寺の明澄に三論教学を学んだ。
sen.e: He studied the Sanron doctrine under Meicho of Gankoji Temple in Nara.
When he was fourteen, he studied the Sanron doctrine under Meicho of Gankoji Temple in Nara.
sen.cmt: 「１４歳で」にあたる言葉を追加しました。
sen.e: When he was fourteen, he studied the Sanron doctrine under Meicho of Gankoji Temple in Nara.

sen.j: 818年（弘仁9年）東大寺で受戒した後、828年（天長5年）神護寺（あるいは東寺）で空海に真言密教を学び灌頂を受けた。
sen.e: In 818, he was ordained as a Buddhist priest by receiving the commandments of Buddhism at Todaiji Temple, and in 828, he studied a form of Esoteric Buddhism 'Shingon Mikkyo' from Kukai at Jingoji Temple (or Toji Temple) and underwent the ritual of consecration.

In 818, he was ordained as a Buddhist priest by receiving the commandments of Buddhism at Todaiji Temple, and in 828, he studied Shingon Mikkyo, a form of Esoteric Buddhism, from Kukai at Jingoji Temple (or Toji Temple) and underwent the ritual of consecration.
sen.cmt: 「a form of」以下（青字）は原文になく、説明と思われるので「Shingon Mikkyo」の後にしました。
sen.e: In 818, he was ordained as a Buddhist priest by receiving the commandments of Buddhism at Todaiji Temple, and in 828, he studied Shingon Mikkyo, a form of Esoteric Buddhism, from Kukai at Jingoji Temple (or Toji Temple) and underwent the ritual of consecration.

sen.j: 以後、興福寺維摩会など様々な法会の講師や導師をつとめ、承和 (日本)年間（834年－848年）には大堰川の堤防を改築するなど行基の再来と称された。
sen.e: Thereafter, he served as an instructor and officiating priest at various religious services including the Yuimae at Kofukuji Temple, and during the Showa era (834 - 848), he reconstructed the Oigawa River embankment, thereby called a second Gyoki.

sen.j: またこの間、836年（承和3年）には広隆寺別当・隆城寺別当を歴任している。
sen.e: During this period, in 836, he successively served as the chief administrator of Koryuji Temple and Ryujoji Temple.

sen.j: 864年（貞観6年）権律師に任じられ4年後に律師となり、874年（貞観16年）には少僧都までいたった。
sen.e: In 864, he was appointed an administrative position Gonrisshi, and four years later, appointed a higher administrative position Risshi, and in 874, raised to Shosozu.
In 864, he was appointed Gonrisshi, an administrative position, four years later as Risshi, a higher administrative position and in 874 up to Shosozu.
sen.cmt: Gonrisshi, Risshiとその説明の順序を入れ替え（説明は原文にはなく、後のほうがいいと思ったので）、raisedをup toにしました。
sen.e: In 864, he was appointed Gonrisshi, an administrative position, four years later as Risshi, a higher administrative position and in 874 up to Shosozu.

sen.j: さらに同じ年嵯峨葛井寺（ふじいでら）を再興して法輪寺 (京都市西京区)と改め、中興開山となった。
sen.e: In the same year, he restored Saga Fujiidera Temple and renamed it Horinji Temple (Saikyo Ward in Kyoto) to become the restorer.
In the same year, he restored Saga Fujiidera Temple and renamed it Horinji Temple (Saikyo Ward in Kyoto) and became the Restoration patriarch.
sen.cmt: to becomeだと動作の主体がTempleになるのではないかと思ったのでandにし、「中興開山」を用語集の訳語にしました。
sen.e: In the same year, he restored Saga Fujiidera Temple and renamed it Horinji Temple (Saikyo Ward in Kyoto) and became the Restoration patriarch.

sen.j: 830年（天長7年）の仏名会に参列した道昌は淳和天皇に召された。
sen.e: In 830, when he attended a religious service Butsumyoe, he was called by Emperor Junna.
In 830, when he attended Butsumyoe, a religious service, he had a talk with Emperor Junna.
sen.cmt: "was called by"→ "had a talk with".Butsumyoeと説明部分の順序を入れ替えました。
sen.e: In 830, when he attended Butsumyoe, a religious service, he had a talk with Emperor Junna.

sen.j: 天皇より「君主の殺生と臣下の殺生のどちらが罪が重いのか？」と尋ねた。
sen.e: The emperor asked him 'Which is more sinful the taking of life by the sovereign and by the retainer?'
The emperor asked him 'Which is more sinful the taking of life by the sovereign and by the retainer?'
The emperor asked him 'Which is the greater sin: the taking of life by a sovereign or the taking of life by a retainer?'
sen.cmt: the taking of life by a retainer?'としました。

sen.j: 道昌は「君主は己の贅沢のために殺生を行うためにその罪は重いが、臣下の中には生活のためにやむを得ず殺生を行う者もいる。
sen.e: Dosho answered, 'The sovereign is more sinful because he kills animals for his luxury, but some retainers are forced to kill animals for making their living.

sen.j: なのに君主はそれすら禁止している」と答えた。
sen.e: But the sovereign forbids that.'
But the sovereign forbids that.'
But the sovereign forbids that.'

sen.j: 天皇はこれを聞いて倹約を行うとともに贅沢のための殺生を戒める一方で、山沢の禁を緩めて貧しい者が狩漁によって食を得ることを許したという（『日本三代実録』『元亨釈書』）。
sen.e: Based on his answer, the emperor lived in frugality and forbid the taking of life for luxury, and relaxed Santaku no Kin to permit the poor and needy to make their living by hunting and fishing ("Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" "Genkoshakusho".)

sen.j: 後に道昌は淳和天皇の皇子で承和の変で廃太子となった恒貞親王が出家した際に弟子としている。
sen.e: Later, when Prince Tsunesada, a son of Emperor Junna, was disinherited in the Jowa incident and took the tonsure, Dosho made him his disciple.
